descriptions:
This interactive globe is a journey through the skies of many worlds—cultural star stories, sacred skywatching sites, and historical astronomical records.

Each point on the map marks a place where the sky and culture meet.

Explore how people across time and place have looked up and made meaning of the cosmos.

Whether you're interested in ancient observatories, cultural myths, documented supernovae and eclipses, or Indigenous lands where modern telescopes reside, this website invites you to rediscover astronomy as a human heritage.

description: A prehistoric megalithic structure on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England
image_desc: The earliest-known realistic painting of Stonehenge, drawn on site with watercolours by Lucas de Heere between 1573 and 1575
descriptions: A prehistoric megalithic structure on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England

At Machu Picchu, celestial alignments and solar markers were built into the site’s architecture, showing how astronomy guided the Incas’ way of life. Image from UNESCO

Read how the Incas saw the stars
Check out educational worksheet from NASA: Math of Machu Pichu's Astronomy

image_desc: Sunset through one of Phanom Rung's doors
descriptions: Orientation of Phanom Rung Temple Related to Cosmical Setting of Spica on Saka New Year Day
As above, so below

description: Originally known as Six Grandfathers, this sacred mountain holds profound spiritual significance for the Lakota people.
descriptions: Long before it became Mount Rushmore, this mountain was known to the Lakota as Six Grandfathers (Tȟuŋkášila Šákpe). Read more...
notes: Long before it became Mount Rushmore, this mountain was known to the Lakota as Six Grandfathers (Tȟuŋkášila Šákpe). Representing the six sacred directions—north, south, east, west, above, and below—it symbolized balance, harmony, and the deep connection between the land and cosmos. As part of the sacred Black Hills, Six Grandfathers was a place of spiritual significance, anchoring the Lakota worldview in unity with nature and the universe.
The mountain was a key part of the Lakota ceremonial landscape, rooted in their deep connection to the Black Hills (*Pahá Sápa*), which they consider the heart of their universe.

The name Six Grandfathers reflects a spiritual geography that aligns the cosmos with the land. The site is a reminder of the Lakota’s enduring relationship with the Black Hills, despite the changes brought by history.

descriptions: Large Binocular Telescope (LBT)
13 telescopes
First mountain-top observatory
Hobbly-Eberly, Harlan J. Smith, Otto Struve, 0.8-m, 0.9-m
MMT, Tillinghast, Hungarian-made Automated Telescope (HAT), MEarth, MINERVA, VERITAS
L200-in (5.1-meter) Hale Telescope, the 48-in (1.2-m) Samuel Oschin Telescope, and the 60-in (1.5-m) telescope
Mayall 4-m, WIYN, McMath-Pierce Solar Telescope, KPNO 2.1 m Telescope, ARO 12m Radio Telescope (ARO12m or KP12m)
Snow Solar Telescope, 60-in, Hooker 100-in
Lowell Discovery Telescope (LDT), Hall Telescope, Schmidt Telescope, 31-in telescope, TiMo, Navy Precision OPtical Interferometer (NPOI)
Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT)
Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT)

description: Detailed accounts from the Song Dynasty observing SN 1006 for over three years.
descriptions: SN 1006: Detailed accounts from the Song Dynasty observing SN 1006 for over three years.
Described as a 'Zhoubo' star with golden-yellow color and pointed rays.
Recorded in multiple texts including Songshi and Song Huiyao; visible from 1 May 1006, reappearing regularly until 1009.

description: Japanese record describes SN 1006 as bright and scintillating, visible in the southern sky.
descriptions: SN 1006: Japanese record describes SN 1006 as bright and scintillating, visible in the southern sky.
Recorded in Meigetsuki, compiled by Fujiwara Sadaie.
Compared to Mars and seen in Qiguan for multiple nights.

description: Ali ibn Ridwan described SN 1006 as bright as the quarter Moon.
descriptions: SN 1006: Ali ibn Ridwan described SN 1006 as bright as the quarter Moon.
Said to be 2.5–3× the size of Venus; first visible around 30 April 1006, disappeared by 2 September.
Provided one of the most detailed early astrological descriptions.

description: European monks observed SN 1006 as a dazzling southern object visible for three months.
descriptions: SN 1006: European monks observed SN 1006 as a dazzling southern object visible for three months.
Described as 'glittering and dazzling the eyes, causing alarm'.
Low elevation; visibility occasionally blocked by mountains.

description: Yemeni chroniclers described SN 1006 as having rays like the Sun.
descriptions: SN 1006: Yemeni chroniclers described SN 1006 as having rays like the Sun.
Attributed its brightness to the dark, high-altitude skies of Yemen.
No precise dates given, but supports extreme brilliance.

description: Possible Indigenous North American record of SN 1054.
descriptions: Petroglyph with crescent Moon and bright star may represent SN 1054.
Interpretation supported by alignment and dating.

description: Observed SN 1572, also known as Tycho's Supernova.
descriptions: Observed SN 1572, also known as Tycho's Supernova.
Tycho Brahe's observations challenged the idea of an unchanging cosmos.
First modern study of a supernova.

description: Observed SN 1572 during the Ming Dynasty.
descriptions: Observed SN 1572 during the Ming Dynasty.
Recorded as a guest star in official Chinese astronomical records.
Noted for its brightness and celestial position.

description: Observed SN 1604, also known as Kepler's Supernova.
descriptions: Kepler observed and documented this bright supernova in 1604.
The last naked-eye supernova in our galaxy.

description: Observed SN 1604 as a guest star in East Asia.
descriptions: Observed SN 1604 as a guest star in East Asia.
Chinese astronomers recorded its brightness and slow fading.
Corroborated European observations of SN 1604.

description: Observed SN 185, the earliest documented supernova.
descriptions: SN 185: Observed SN 185, the earliest documented supernova.
Recorded in the Book of Later Han, the guest star appeared on 7 December AD 185 and was visible for over 20 months.
Described as variegated and located near the Southern Gate asterism (likely α and β Centauri).

description: Observed SN 1181, recently linked to the Pa 30 nebula.
descriptions: Observed SN 1181, recently linked to the Pa 30 nebula.
Visible for 185 days; described as bright as Saturn.
Modern counterpart identified as a rare Type Iax supernova.

description: Japanese records also describe SN 1181.
descriptions: Japanese records also describe SN 1181.
Historical astronomy aligns with Chinese records.
Observed for nearly six months in Japan.

description: Observed the eruption of Eta Carinae in the 1840s.
descriptions: Observed the eruption of Eta Carinae in the 1840s.
Boorong people recorded the Great Eruption of Eta Carinae as Collowgullouric War.
This is the only known Indigenous observation of the outburst.

description: Observed SN 1987A, closest visible supernova since 1604.
descriptions: Observed SN 1987A, closest visible supernova since 1604.
First identified by Shelton and Duhalde in the southern hemisphere.
Led to a new era of supernova studies.

description: Detected neutrinos from SN 1987A.
descriptions: Kamiokande II detected neutrinos from SN 1987A before the optical signal arrived.
Confirmed theoretical models of core-collapse supernovae.

description: Optical monitoring of SN 1987A.
descriptions: Optical monitoring of SN 1987A.
Generated detailed light curves and spectra over months.
Helped trace the evolution of the shockwave and ring structure.

description: Observed Halley's Comet in 240 BCE, described as a 'broom star'.
descriptions: Observed Halley's Comet in 240 BCE, described as a 'broom star'.
First confirmed sighting of Halley's Comet in Chinese records.
Observed over a period of several weeks.

description: Observed Halley's Comet in 12 BCE, interpreted as an omen.
descriptions: Observed Halley's Comet in 12 BCE, interpreted as an omen.
Linked to Agrippa's death and Caesar's comet by Roman observers.

description: Observed Halley's Comet in 1066, depicted in the Bayeux Tapestry.
descriptions: Observed Halley's Comet in 1066, depicted in the Bayeux Tapestry.
The comet was seen as a powerful omen before the Norman conquest.

description: Observed Halley's Comet in 1910, during a time of public panic and fascination.
descriptions: Observed Halley's Comet in 1910, during a time of public panic and fascination.
Believed to carry toxic gases; spurred social and scientific curiosity.

site_name: Peñasco Blanco, Chaco Canyon, New Mexico
description: Pictograph possibly depicting the 1054 CE supernova (SN 1054), observed by the Ancestral Puebloans.
descriptions: Pictograph possibly depicting the 1054 CE supernova (SN 1054), observed by the Ancestral Puebloans.
The pictograph features a crescent moon, a radiant star-like symbol, and a handprint.
Located near the Peñasco Blanco great house in Chaco Canyon, this site is accessible via a 9-mile round-trip hike.
The alignment of the crescent and star suggests a representation of the supernova observed in July 1054 CE.
As we gaze upward, let us remember the connections between the sky, land, and life—and our responsibility to protect them for generations to come.
